ÅšÄriputra!
To the east, past ninety-two thousand buddha-lands, there is a world called Good Flower. In that land there is a buddha named Pure Abiding.

There is a bodhisattva named Ratnamukuá¹­a who, together with eight thousand bodhisattvas, has come here and is expounding the Dharma. His voice is heard throughout the great trichiliocosm, encouraging sentient beings to cultivate wholesome dharmas.

At that time, the bodhisattva Ratnamukuá¹­a, together with eight thousand bodhisattvas and innumerable humans and devas, came to where the Buddha was, bowed their heads to his feet, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata ViÅ›uddhaÂ­sthÄna of the world Good Flower pays homage and inquires about your well-being:
Are you at ease in your daily activities? Do you have any difficulties?
Are your retinue and great assembly happily receiving the Dharma?
World-Honored One!
I have come from there to this world to listen to the Dharma seal of the pure practices of bodhisattvas.

May the TathÄgata, out of great compassion for all, explain and analyze this, so that the bodhisattvas, upon hearing it, will cultivate and destroy all afflictive habits, practice the bodhisattva path, understand the minds of all beings, be able to cultivate the characteristics of the bodhisattvas, be able to comprehend the practices of wisdom, be able to understand the practices of all afflictions, be able to cultivate the Dharma practices cultivated by the bodhisattvas, be able to deeply observe all faults, and attain unobstructed vision of all buddhas with their bodies.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
I will now explain one-tenth of such pure practices.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have four practices.
What are the four?
First, the practice of pÄramitÄs;
second, the practice of assisting enlightenment;
third, the practice of spiritual powers;
Fourth, the practice of taming sentient beings.
The practice of pÄramitÄs is the skillful means of vows.
The practice of assisting enlightenment is the skillful means of cultivating the path.
The practice of spiritual powers is the skillful means of taming the mind.
The skillful means of taming the mind is the skillful means of solidifying the bodhi mind.
Good man!
What is called dÄna pÄramitÄ?
DÄna pÄramitÄ is pure conduct, which can destroy deluded thoughts and cultivate the mind of abandonment. Having cultivated the mind of abandonment, one can give everything.
If there are bodhisattvas who can give everything, they will attain four kinds of non-discriminating minds.
What are the four?
First, not discriminating sentient beings;
Second, not discriminating dharmas;
Third, not discriminating the mind;
Fourth, not discriminating vows. These are called the four.

Not discriminating sentient beings, thinking 'This one can be given to, this one cannot be given to,' 'This one should be given much, this one should be given little,' 'This one should be given superior, this one should be given inferior,' 'This one should be given respectfully, this one should be given contemptuously,' 'This one should be given in full, this one should be given half,' 'This one is a keeper of precepts, this one is a violator of precepts,' 'This one is a field of merit, this one is not a field of merit,' 'This one will obtain great rewards, this one will not obtain great rewards,' 'This one has right views, this one has wrong views.'
'This one practices the right aggregate, this one practices the wrong aggregate.'
Good son!
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attains such a mind, it is called the mind of non-discrimination, the mind without arrogance, the mind without high and low, the mind without obstruction.

This is the mind of equality, the mind of true reality, the equality of giving and precepts, the equality of kindness and compassion, without discrimination, just like empty space. This is called 'not discriminating sentient beings.'
Not discriminating the Dharma means that a bodhisattva never discriminates like this: 'For those who accept, I will explain; for those who do not accept, I will not explain;'
Those who accept the Dharma are provided with what they need, while those who do not accept the Dharma are not supplied.
One never considers that ordinary people are unworthy of giving, while the sages are worthy of giving. This is called the Dharma of non-discrimination.
As for the mind of non-discrimination, one observes the minds of all sentient beings as being equal, not giving in return;
Without internal or external greed, not giving for fame, not seeking results in giving.
The beloved things are given away without regret, and giving is practiced in order to gather sentient beings. This is called the mind of non-discrimination.

As for the vow of non-discrimination, when giving, one does not do so in order to attain the body of Åšakra, the body of BrahmÄ, the body of a wheel-turning king, the body of a demon, the body of an elder or great minister, nor does one do so for great freedom or great retinue.

Not for the sake of the upper realms, not for the sake of the ÅšrÄvaka and Pratyekabuddha vehicles, up to not for the sake of supreme, perfect enlightenment, one practices giving. This is called the vow of non-discrimination.
Good son!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate giving, if they fully accomplish these four things, they will then be able to distance themselves from the eight wrong views:
First, the view of self;
Second, the view of sentient beings;
Third, the view of life;
Fourth, the view of personhood;
Fifth, the view of permanence;
Sixth, the view of annihilation;
Seventh, the view of existence;
Eighth, the view of non-existence. These are called the eight.
They will also be able to distance themselves from four kinds of merits:
First, the merits of ordinary beings;
Second, the merits of Å›rÄvakas;
Third, the merits of pratyekabuddhas;
Fourth, the merits of residual habits.
Having given like this, one does not observe four characteristics:
First, the characteristic of permanence;
second, the characteristic of bliss;
third, the characteristic of self;
fourth, the characteristic of purity.
One is able to purify four dharmas:
First, purifying the body;
second, purifying the mouth;
third, purifying the mind;
fourth, purifying vows.
One is far removed from three hindrances:
First, the hindrance of karmic retribution;
second, the hindrance of Å›rÄvakas;
third, the hindrance of remorse.
Good sons!
When a bodhisattva practices such giving, he is far removed from three fears:ğŸ”½First, the fear of arrogance;
second, the fear of conceit;
third, the fear of the activities of MÄra.
When a bodhisattva practices such giving, he possesses four kinds of seals:ğŸ”½First, the seal of inner emptiness;
second, the seal of outer emptiness;
third, the seal of the emptiness of sentient beings;

When practicing such giving, one possesses four kinds of diligence:
First, in order to fulfill sentient beings, one must be fully diligent;
Second, in order to protect the Buddha's teachings, one must be fully diligent;
Third, in order to attain the thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics, one must be fully diligent;
Fourth, in order to purify the Buddha-land, one must be fully diligent.
At that time, one will also attain the four kinds of mindfulness:
First, mindfulness of the bodhi mind;
Second, mindfulness of the desire to see the Buddha;
Third, the mind always mindful of kindness;
Fourth, mindfulness of leaving afflictions.
When making such offerings, one purifies three things:
First, one's own body;
Second, the bodies of others;
Third, bodhi.
When making such offerings, one purifies four kinds of wisdom:
First, the wisdom of realms;
Second, the wisdom of fulfilling sentient beings;
Third, the wisdom of vows;
Fourth, the wisdom of assisting bodhi.
Good man!
If bodhisattvas are able to practice such dharmas, they will be able to purify the perfection of giving.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattvas purify the practice of the perfection of morality?
Good sons!

There is one kind of purity, which is to say that bodhisattvas have compassion for all sentient beings in the world, surpassing the compassion of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, able to destroy the activities of MÄra and tame all sentient beings, replete with the accumulation of immeasurable merit and virtue, without negligence.
There are also two kinds:
First, not giving rise to an evil mind towards any sentient being.
Second, taming all sentient beings and causing them to turn towards enlightenment.
There are also three kinds:
First, purifying the body, because it is far removed from all evil physical actions;
second, purifying the mouth, because it is far removed from all evil verbal actions;
third, purifying the mind, because it is far removed from all greed, anger, and wrong views.
There are also four kinds:
First, encouraging sentient beings to uphold precepts;
Second, encouraging sentient beings to be fully endowed with pure precepts;
Third, being able to discipline those who violate precepts;
Fourth, seeing those who uphold precepts, making offerings, paying respect, venerating, and praising them.
There are also five kinds:
First, having upheld precepts, not giving rise to arrogance;
Second, seeing those who violate precepts, not giving rise to contempt;
Third, seeing those who uphold precepts, the mind free from jealousy;
Fourth, never seeking the vehicle of Å›rÄvakas;
Fifth, not thinking of the vehicle of pratyekabuddhas.
There are also six kinds:
First, recollecting the Buddha, because of surpassing precepts;
Second, recollecting the Dharma, because after surpassing precepts, the mind does not give rise to regret;
Third, recollecting the Saá¹…gha, because of being able to fully possess the TathÄgata's precepts;
Fourth, recollecting the precepts, because of not seeking the fruits and rewards of various existences;
Fifth, recollecting giving, because of being able to give everything;
Sixth, mindfulness of the gods, in order to be fully endowed with all wholesome dharmas.
There are also seven kinds:
First, deeply believing in all the Buddha-Dharmas;
Second, diligently practicing with vigor in order to attain the Buddha-Dharmas;
Third, being endowed with wisdom in order to understand all the Buddha-Dharmas;
Fourth, being able to expound all the Buddha-Dharmas after hearing them;
Fifth, making offerings to one's parents, teachers, and preceptors;
Sixth, fearing present and future evil karma;
Seventh, having a sense of shame and remorse.
There are also eight kinds:
First, not seeking to profit or amaze the assembly by displaying strange things;
Second, not speaking of one's own affairs, being detached from everything;
Third, not praising offerings, being content in one's mind;
Fourth, practicing the holy lineage, delighting in wholesome dharmas;
Fifth, following the dhÅ«ta practices, not cherishing one's body and life;
Sixth, they delight in tranquility and avoid worldly affairs;
Seventh, they deeply delight in the Dharma and are disgusted with the three realms;
Eighth, they wholeheartedly protect the Dharma and do not begrudge their bodies or lives.
There are also nine kinds:
First, they are free from the nine evil minds and transcend the nine abodes of sentient beings;
Second, their thoughts are pure;
Third, they contemplate cultivation;
Fourth, they increase wholesome dharmas;
Fifth, their minds delight in tranquility;
Sixth, they are free from the heat of afflictions;
Seventh, they adorn Å›amatha;
Eighth, they diligently practice vigor;
Ninth, they do not deceive sentient beings.
There are also ten kinds:
First, they purify the three karmas of the body;
Second, they purify the four karmas of speech;
Third, they purify the three karmas of the mind;
Fourth, they are free from jealousy;
Fifth, they are free from flattery;
Sixth, they wholeheartedly contemplate the precepts;
seventh, for the sake of upholding the precepts, diligently practicing and making energetic progress;
eighth, gentle speech, in order to tame sentient beings;
ninth, accepting a body as a servant for sentient beings;
tenth, not giving rise to contempt towards all fields of blessings.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas cultivating the perfection of morality have two kinds of pure practices:
first, with mind, with characteristics, and with adornments, they would rather give up their lives than violate the precepts;
second, without mind, without characteristics, and without adornments, their minds are not attached to any dharmas.
There are also two kinds.
First, purifying the internal sense bases.
Second, not seeking any external sense bases.
There are also two kinds:
first, always aspiring for the mind of enlightenment;
second, not observing the characteristics of the precepts that were originally directed towards enlightenment.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas purify the practice of the perfection of patience?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not retaliate when scolded, because their verbal karma is pure;

Good man!
Although bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas endure insults, they do not retaliate, in order to protect sentient beings;
they endure all kinds of harm and do not retaliate, in order to protect future lives;
they do not become angry with a compassionate mind when their hands and feet are cut off, in order to protect bodhi.

Seeing those who come to beg, they do not give rise to anger, in order to engage in the four means of gathering disciples, in order to give rise to a compassionate mind, in order to increase the path to bodhi, and in order to destroy stingy and greedy thoughts and destroy the work of MÄra.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having cultivated mindfulness of the Buddha, practice patience and endure all suffering, in order to attain the Buddha's body.
Good man!
There are also bodhisattvas who cultivate patience, in order to fully attain the ten powers.
There are also bodhisattvas who cultivate patience in order to achieve the great lion's roar.
There are also those who cultivate patience in order to know the three times without obstruction.
There are also those who cultivate patience in order to attain the power of great kindness and great compassion.
There are also those who cultivate patience in order to attain complete omniscience.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess two powers can accomplish patience:
First, the power of wisdom;
Second, the power of cultivation.
Because of the power of wisdom, they contemplate the body and mind, and therefore practice patience.
Because of the power of cultivation, they are not attached to dharmas, and therefore practice patience.
Furthermore, good man!
The bodhisattva who purifies patience is able to contemplate that there are no sentient beings in all dharmas, and therefore cultivates patience.
All dharmas are by nature liberated, and therefore the bodhisattva contemplates all dharmas as being neither patient nor angry.
If the mind is not attached to dharmas, this is called patience.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas have two kinds of patience:
The first is contemplating the Dharma body;
The second is contemplating the Dharma realm.
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to contemplate these two dharmas in this way, this is called the bodhisattva's practice of purifying the perfection of patience.
Good sons!
What is the bodhisattva's practice of purifying the perfection of vigor?

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not cease or regret their various practices, are not content with their minds in regard to various wholesome dharmas, also enjoy practicing the five perfections, always seek to adorn all wholesome dharmas, protect the true Dharma and enjoy expounding it,

tame sentient beings without resting their minds, surpass the vehicles of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, protect all the true Dharma of the buddhas, cultivate various austerities without regret in their minds, never lose their wholesome roots from the past, extensively cultivate learning without being weary, and do not give rise to sorrow or regret in running errands for the multitude, this is called vigor.
What is meant by pure diligence?

If one can contemplate the body as a reflection, the mouth as speechless, and the mind as ultimately pure, using the wisdom of exhaustion to contemplate all extinguished phenomena, and using the wisdom of non-arising to know the end of all existences,
when contemplating in this way, one can adorn three kinds of diligence:
First, the adornment of the essence;
Second, the adornment of enlightenment;
Third, the adornment of discrimination.
There are also three kinds of non-attached diligence:
First, not attached to the eyes;
Second, not attached to forms;
Third, not attached to consciousness.
Up to the Dharma, it is also like this, this is called non-grasping and non-abandoning diligence.

Having perfected such diligent effort, one does not grasp at generosity and abandon stinginess, does not grasp at upholding precepts and abandon violating precepts, does not grasp at patience and abandon anger, does not grasp at vigor and abandon laziness, does not grasp at meditation and abandon a distracted mind, does not grasp at wisdom and abandon foolishness, does not grasp at wholesome dharmas and abandon unwholesome dharmas, does not grasp at the Buddha's path and abandon the two vehicles. This is called the two kinds of diligent effort. These two kinds of effort can perfect the Buddha's Dharma.
There are also two kinds:
Namely, internal and external.
If a bodhisattva is able to cultivate such diligent effort, this is called the practice of purifying the perfection of vigor.
Good man!
How does a bodhisattva purify the practice of the perfection of meditation?
If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva takes up the factors of meditation and contemplates the factors of meditation, having contemplated, he enters concentration.
Having entered concentration, he does not crave for form, feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness. This is called meditation.
Not attached to eye dhyÄna, up to mind dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.
Not attached to form dhyÄna, up to dharma dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.
Not attached to earth, water, fire, wind, space dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.
Not attached to sun, moon, Åšakra, BrahmÄ, ÄªÅ›vara dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.

Not attached to the characteristics of sentient beings, life, person, self, and human dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.ğŸ”½Not attached to eternalism, annihilationism, existence, non-existence dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.ğŸ”½Not ultimately exhausting defilements dhyÄna, this is called dhyÄna.

It is not the attainment of the fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as and dhyÄna. Such dhyÄna is not the ultimate practice of dhyÄna, and is called the dhyÄna of empty discipline, not the dhyÄna of true emptiness;

This bodhisattva is fully endowed with the dhyÄna of great compassion and all empty practices.
What is meant by being endowed with all emptiness?

If one does not contemplate giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, wisdom, skillful means, compassion, joy, the four truths, the wisdom of enlightenment, the adornments of vows, Å›amatha, vipaÅ›yanÄ, liberation, shame, and conscience, this is called the unobstructed wisdom of the buddhas' skillful means, samÄdhi, and spiritual powers.

Embracing the ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha, not being tainted by the two vehicles, severing all habitual tendencies, fully possessing immeasurable wisdom of great spiritual powers, being the refuge of all beings.

Adorning worldly and supramundane dharmas, skillfully subduing all beings, crossing the four currents and the great ocean of birth and death, able to sever all bonds, purifying the nature of all dharmas, this is called the nature of quiescence.

Not heading towards the quiescence of dharmas, also grasping the nature of heading towards dharmas and abandoning them, clearly heading towards the nature of dharmas and blindness, having heard heading towards the nature of dharmas and deafness, diligently subduing heading towards the nature of dharmas and stagnation, cool extinction and quiescence, subduing and burning, this is called the emptiness of all activities.
Good man!

It is like the beings in the trichiliocosm, all skilled in painting, some good at applying mud, some good at grinding colors, some understanding how to paint the body but not the hands and feet, some understanding the hands and feet but not the facial features.
At that time, a king gave a piece of silk to these people and told them:
All who can paint, come gather here and paint a portrait of me on this silk.
Then, the people all gathered and according to their abilities, they worked together to complete it.
There was one painter who did not come because of circumstances.
The people finished the painting and brought it to the king.
Good man!
Can it be said that all the people gathered to do it?
No, World-Honored One!
Good man!
I tell this parable, but its meaning is not yet clear.
Good man!
If one person does not come, one cannot say that everyone has gathered, nor can one say that the image is already complete.

The practice of the Buddha's Dharma is also like this. If there is one practice that is not accomplished, it cannot be called the perfect Dharma of the TathÄgata. Therefore, one must fully possess all practices in order to be called the accomplishment of unsurpassed enlightenment.
When this Dharma was being spoken, sixty thousand bodhisattvas attained the perfection of emptiness in all practices.
Good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas purify prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas possess twelve kinds of wisdom:
First, knowing the past without obstruction;ğŸ”½Second, knowing the future without obstruction;
Third, knowing the present without obstruction;ğŸ”½Fourth, knowing conditioned arising without obstruction;
Fifth, knowing unconditioned arising without obstruction;ğŸ”½Sixth, knowing the worldly without obstruction;
Seventh, knowing the supramundane without obstruction;
Eighth, knowing unobstructed eloquence;ğŸ”½ninth, knowing the unobstructed reality;ğŸ”½tenth, knowing the unobstructed conventional truth;
eleventh, knowing the unobstructed ultimate truth;
twelfth, knowing the unobstructed sharpness and dullness of sentient beings. This is called wisdom.

It is difficult to destroy but can destroy, difficult to observe but can observe, difficult to understand but can understand. It is like a vajra that cannot be destroyed. This is called the wisdom of the world, the ultimate wisdom, the true wisdom of all sentient beings.

It is difficult to practice, difficult to enter, difficult to see, very profound, difficult to study and learn. Right view and right accumulation, far from all views and habitual tendencies, knowing and seeing the minds of all sentient beings clearly by oneself, knowing the Dharma and knowing the meaning without attachment, vast light, free from disputes and narrow-mindedness.

Knowing the proper time and not exceeding the proper time, protecting the aggregate of the true Dharma, ultimately realizing true enlightenment and true awakening, far removed from defilements and not reproached by anyone.

A single practice is no practice, the practice of all sentient beings is no practice, although there are no traces of practice, although one is apart from all worldly practices, one is also not far removed from all worldly practices.
Although apart from the world, not apart from the Buddha-land, although apart from all adornments of practice, also not far removed from taming sentient beings.

Although apart from practices, not apart from good practices, although apart from the causes and conditions of sentient beings' mental activities, not apart from knowing sentient beings' mental activities.
Although apart from worldly practices, not apart from worldly dharmas, although apart from all bodies, also entering sentient beings' minds - this is called wisdom.

Such wisdom is extremely difficult to attain. If one's wholesome roots are not fully mature, one will never be able to obtain it. If one cannot always practice good dharmas, one will also be unable to attain such wisdom.

It can only be attained under the Bodhi tree. Truly knowing the nature of dharmas, protected by the buddhas, crossing to the other shore, knowing all dharmas and bestowing the taste of immortality, therefore it is called prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.
Good sons!
Such wisdom ultimately knows all conditions, all characteristics, and the mental activities of all sentient beings. For this reason, it is called wisdom.
Such wisdom has two kinds of tranquility:
First, knowing the tranquility of the characteristics of obstruction;
Second, knowing the tranquility of the characteristics of non-obstruction.
There are also two kinds:
First, the purity of non-perception;
Second, the purity of being free from all views.

Such wisdom, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always roam within the faculties of sentient beings, whether sharp or dull, within the minds of sentient beings, and within all dharmas, observing that afflictions are precisely wisdom.

Although bodhisattvas abide in the various realms, they mostly abide in the Buddha realm, able to observe and see the worlds in the ten directions, free from all obstructions, all of which are the roots of all Buddha-dharmas, replete with all unsurpassed Buddha-dharmas, not learning any dharmas, not leaving behind any dharmas, not destroying any dharmas, not accomplishing any dharmas.

Bodhisattvas who accomplish such wisdom are able to create merit, able to read, recite, and explain all Buddha-dharmas, able to attain all blessings and virtues, and able to cultivate and accomplish all wholesome dharmas. This is called the bodhisattvas' pure practice of prajÃ±Ä-pÄramitÄ.

When this Dharma was being taught, 22,000 sentient beings gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, 8,000 bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, 500 bhiká¹£us exhausted their contaminations and their minds were liberated, and 10,000 devas and humans attained the fruit of stream-entry.
At that time, all the devas and humans spoke with one voice, saying:
World-Honored One!
If there are people who can believe in this sÅ«tra, one should know that such people are protected by the buddhas, let alone those who are able to uphold, recite, copy, and make offerings to it!
Good sons!
How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas purify the practice of enlightenment?
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the mindfulness of the body, which has two kinds of practices:
First, the practice of impurity;
Second, the practice of purity.
The practice of impurity is to contemplate the body as impure, filled with foul odors, impermanent, and not abiding, deceiving ordinary beings.
The practice of purity is for bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas to think like this:
'I now, because of this impure body, attain the pure buddha-body, attain the pure dharma-body, the pure body of merit and virtue, a body that all beings delight in seeing.'
Furthermore, good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the body and the body, and are able to purify two practices:
First, impermanence;
Second, it is constant.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the impermanence of the body and are certain to die. Having contemplated in this way, they do not create evil karma for the sake of the body or sustain themselves through wrong livelihood. They cultivate the three firm dharmas:
First, the firmness of the body;
Second, the firmness of life;
Third, the firmness of wealth.
Having contemplated in this way, they are able to serve sentient beings and immediately attain the avoidance of crookedness in body, speech, and mind.
The bodhisattvas, contemplating the body in this way as impermanent, attain immeasurable merits such as these.
What is meant by constant?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having contemplated impermanence, attain a permanent body. Because of impermanence, they attain a body of merit. Because of impermanence, they do not sever the lineage of the Buddha, the lineage of the Dharma, or the lineage of the Saá¹ƒgha.
Good man!
Moreover, constant means inexhaustible. Inexhaustible means unconditioned. The unconditioned is the domain of omniscience. The domain of omniscience is emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness.
Moreover, permanence is precisely emptiness. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate all dharmas as being like emptiness. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' practice of permanence.
Good sons!

Moreover, there are bodhisattvas who cultivate the mindfulness of the body and observe that the bodies of all sentient beings will ultimately be the tathÄgata's buddha-body. Just as the tathÄgata's body is the dharma-body, so too are these two bodies my body as well. This is called the bodhisattva's observation of the uncontaminated body.
At that time, the wholesome dharmas obtained by the bodhisattva, to the extent of their many or few, are all uncontaminated.
With such dharmas, he makes vows and dedicates them to the cognition of all aspects. Having attained the uncontaminated, he never again gives rise to contamination.
What is called contamination are precisely the three contaminations, namely the contamination of desire, the contamination of existence, and the contamination of ignorance.

The bodhisattva, having clearly understood the three contaminations, is born in the desire realm for the sake of sentient beings, and is also not defiled by the contamination of desire. The form and formless realms are also like this.
The root of the defilement of ignorance has already been pulled out.
Why is it so?
Because by pulling out ignorance, the defilement of views is also absent.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having cultivated mindfulness of the body, do not see self or what belongs to self in this body, and do not give rise to arrogance. Because they are free from self and what belongs to self, they do not seek or grasp at any possessions.
Because they do not seek or grasp, they have no disputes over things. Because they have no disputes, they are in a state of tranquility. Tranquility is precisely patience.
Abiding in patience, they are neither elevated nor debased. Being neither elevated nor debase, they abide in accordance with the Dharma.
Those who abide in accordance with the Dharma do not practice good dharmas and do not practice evil dharmas. Not being elevated or debased, they then attain good friends.
Having attained good friends, they encounter good and virtuous friends. Because they encounter good and virtuous friends, they get to hear the true Dharma.
Because they hear the true Dharma, they do not approach defiled dharmas with a defiled mind. This is called transcending the realm of all defilements.
Having transcended defiled objects, they always enter meditation. Having entered meditation, not a single dharma arises that gives rise to discursive thought.
Because there is no discursive thought, they do not create a single dharma and do not change a single dharma. This is called the true dharma, this is called the equality of all dharmas.
If one attains the equality of all dharmas, this is called omniscience.
Good sons!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to contemplate the mindfulness of the body in this way, this is called contemplating the body and the mindfulness of the body.
Good sons!
At that time, the bodhisattva next contemplates the mindfulness of feelings. Towards those who have feelings, he gives rise to a mind of compassion and says to sentient beings:
One who is ultimately blissful cuts off all feelings.
If a person is able to cut off all feelings, then he is permanently blissful.
At that time, the bodhisattva, following the feelings, gives rise to a mind of compassion.
Whether it is oneself or others, when experiencing a pleasant feeling, one should distance oneself from a mind of craving and give rise to a mind of kindness.
When experiencing suffering, they distance themselves from hateful thoughts and give rise to thoughts of compassion.
When experiencing neither suffering nor happiness, they distance themselves from ignorant thoughts and give rise to thoughts of equanimity.

Therefore, when bodhisattvas experience pleasant feelings, they do not give rise to craving; when experiencing painful feelings, they do not give rise to anger; when experiencing neither pleasant nor painful feelings, they do not give rise to ignorance.
At that time, bodhisattvas contemplate all feelings as impermanent, suffering, and without self. Seeing those who experience pleasure, they know it to be suffering.
Seeing those who experience pain, it is like a boil or a wound.
Seeing those who experience neither pain nor pleasure, it is not tranquil.
Contemplating pleasant feelings is precisely impermanence, contemplating painful feelings is precisely emptiness and non-existence, and neither pleasant nor painful feelings is precisely non-self.
When bodhisattvas contemplate in this way, they see that these feelings are precisely non-feelings, and see that all feelings are conditioned.
If they are conditioned, they are precisely arising, ceasing, dispersing, leaking, and not abiding.
Having contemplated in this way, one does not see a self and does not see a recipient. This is called the great wisdom and skillful means of the bodhisattva.

Based on this skillful means, one sees that all feelings are impermanent and arise and cease. One contemplates that all dharmas are empty, without a recipient or one who receives, without creation or one who creates, arising from conditions and ceasing due to conditions, without belonging to anything or being grasped, and does not give rise to thoughts or speculation regarding causes and conditions.
Based on the absence of thoughts and speculation, one makes the following statement:
'The dharmas of causes and conditions are all empty.'

When the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva contemplates in this way, they accomplish the mindfulness of feelings and are able to cause body and mind to be completely tranquil. Knowing all practices, this is called omniscience. This is called the mindfulness of feelings with regard to feelings.
How do bodhisattvas cultivate the mindfulness of mind?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the mind of enlightenment and contemplate the nature of this mind, not seeing the mind within the internal sense bases, not seeing the mind outside the external sense bases, not seeing the mind within and without the sense bases, not seeing the mind within the aggregates, not seeing the mind within the elements.
Having not seen, they think like this:
'Is the mind's condition like this, different or not different?
If the mind is different from the condition, then in one moment there should be two minds.
If the mind is the condition, then it should not be able to observe its own mind, just as the tip of a finger cannot touch itself, and the mind is also like this.'

Having contemplated like this, they see the mind as without abode, impermanent and changing, and the place of the condition extinguished. They immediately know that this mind is not born from conditions, not not born from conditions, not permanent, not cut off, not internal, not external, not existent, not nonexistent.
Contemplating the mind like this, it does not obstruct knowing the mind as tranquil in accordance with the Dharma. This is called the bodhisattvas' cultivation of the mindfulness of the mind.
Moreover, good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe that the mind is not form and cannot be seen, and is not conceptualization. This is called the bodhisattvas' cultivation of the mindfulness of mind.
As with the mind, so it is with mental factors;
as with mental factors, so it is with mental activities;
as with mental activities, so it is with the dharmas sought by the mind;
as with the dharmas sought, so it is with enlightenment;
as with enlightenment, so it is with all wholesome dharmas.

If bodhisattvas observe the mind to be like a monkey, drawing water, morning dew, a bee, a fish mother, a river, a flame, like conceptualizing distant matters, solitary, without a body, always turning without stopping, attached to the various realms, sequentially arising and ceasing,

they are able to gather such immeasurable minds, causing them to abide in one place, unmoving and unchanging, without leaking, without error, without confusion, without scattering. This is called Å›amatha.

If bodhisattvas are able to contemplate in this way, it is called accomplishing the contemplation of the mind's mindfulness of the mind, it is called knowing the mind's realm, it is called knowing the mind's Dharma realm, it is called knowing the mind's true characteristics, it is called knowing the mind's true nature.
It is the same as extensive knowledge, it is the same as true pure knowledge, it is the same as knowing true knowledge as real and illusory, this is called knowing the Dharma.
It is called knowing the mind's nature, it is called knowing the mind's exhaustion, it is called ungraspable knowledge, unobstructed knowledge.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having contemplated in this way, well know the mind-nature of all sentient beings. Knowing this, they expound the Dharma as is appropriate.ğŸ”½Just as they know their own mind-nature, they know the mind-nature of all sentient beings in the same way.ğŸ”½Just as they know the characteristics of their own mind, they know the characteristics of the minds of all sentient beings in the same way.
Just as they know their own mind is empty, they know the minds of all sentient beings are empty in the same way.
Just as one observes one's own mind as equal, one observes the minds of all sentient beings as equal in the same way.
Having made this observation, one does not move from the dharma realm. This is called a bodhisattva cultivating the mindfulness of mind.
Good man!
How does a bodhisattva cultivate the mindfulness of dharmas?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas make this kind of observation: dharmas arise and dharmas cease, without self, sentient beings, lifespan, or person. Without arising or ceasing, without perishing or emerging, this is called the nature of dharmas.
If one is able to seek the Dharma, this is called the arising of dharmas;
if one does not seek the Dharma, this is called the cessation of dharmas;
whether good or not good, arising follows conditions, and ceasing follows conditions.
When observing in this way, one observes the three kinds of actions, namely unwholesome actions, wholesome actions, and immovable actions.
Within these three kinds of actions, I should always practice the wholesome and good actions, for the sake of the ten wholesome deeds.

Purifying verbal actions, whatever he says, the assembly delights in listening and accepting.
Purifying mental actions, his mind is impartial towards all beings, always entering meditation.

Purifying the four unobstructed understandings, purifying the mind of kindness, therefore bestowing happiness to beings, purifying the mind of compassion, therefore for immeasurable eons enduring suffering for beings without regret;
Purifying the ten powers, in order to know the sharp and dull faculties of beings;
Purifying the four fearlessnesses, in order to know the obstructions and non-obstructions of beings;
Purifying the eighteen dharmas, in order to know the unobstructed three times;
Purifying all Buddha-dharmas, in order to be invincible to all beings.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who are able to contemplate in this way will not be content with the good dharmas and merits, but will cultivate good conduct and abandon evil conduct and the habits of afflictions. They will truly understand the unmoving practice.

Although they know not to be greedy, their minds attain mastery, and they are born according to their vows, not born from karmic bonds. They are born in the desire realm for the sake of sentient beings.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain skillful means, contemplate the mindfulness of dharmas, cultivate and adorn the dharmas that assist in attaining enlightenment, and abandon all the defilements that obstruct enlightenment.
Attaining these merits, they do not cling to the view of permanence or the view of annihilation. Free from these two views, they practice the middle way.
The middle way has two kinds of dharmas:

Second, ignorance. The mind is not negligent in the midst of these two dharmas, and this is called the middle way.
There are also two dharmas:
First, action;
Second, consciousness.
There are two more dharmas:
First, name and form;
Second, the six sense bases.
There are two more dharmas:
First, contact;
Second, feeling.
There are two more dharmas:
First, craving;
Second, grasping.
There are two more dharmas:
First, becoming;
Second, birth.
There are two more dharmas:
First, old age;
Second, death.
Not being negligent within these two dharmas is called the middle way.
Such a middle way cannot be seen by worldly wisdom, cannot be spoken, cannot be revealed, has no characteristics, no form, no location, no grasping, and no abandoning. It is pure and tranquil.
Good man!

The middle way cannot be seen by the eyes, up to it cannot be touched by touch. It also has no destination, is both worldly and transcendent, cannot be spoken of, is neither many nor few. Therefore, it is called the middle way.
Good man!
The names 'I' and 'non-self' are called the two extremes.

If someone says 'neither eternal nor annihilated, neither life nor person, neither thought nor non-thought, neither awareness nor non-awareness, neither real nor false, neither this nor that, neither existent nor non-existent, neither conditioned nor unconditioned, neither action nor non-action, neither birth and death nor nirvana';
Not making such statements is called the middle way.
Furthermore, good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate the Dharma and the mindfulness of the Dharma, without discriminating the Dharma realm;
Just as the Dharma realm, the realm of sentient beings is also like this.
These two realms are called the realm of space, and all dharmas are included in the Dharma realm.
The Dharma realm is precisely the realm of sentient beings, and the realm of sentient beings is without discrimination, this is called the observation of all dharmas.
Equally seeing all realms is precisely the Dharma realm, although clearly seen, the mind is not attached, and because of non-attachment, there is no discrimination.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not contemplate the mindfulness of dharmas with the flesh eye, the heavenly eye, or the wisdom eye.
Why is this?
Because these three eyes have no characteristics.

Therefore, contemplating dharmas is done with the Dharma eye. Although one clearly understands, the mind is not attached. Although one is not attached, one does not lose the Dharma realm. This is called the Buddha's wisdom.
Being able to know such a profound Dharma realm, yet not losing the mindfulness of omniscience, this is called the bodhisattva's cultivation of the mindfulness of dharmas in dharmas.
Good man!
Why do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate these four mindfulnesses?
It is in order to be far removed from the four inverted views.

Cultivating the mindfulness of the body is to be free from the inversion of purity. Cultivating the mindfulness of feelings is to be free from the inversion of happiness. Cultivating the mindfulness of mind is to be free from the inversion of permanence. Cultivating the mindfulness of dharmas is to be free from the inversion of self.

Furthermore, apart from the four foods, cultivating the mindfulness of the body is apart from the food of morsels, cultivating the mindfulness of feelings is apart from the food of contact, cultivating the mindfulness of mind is apart from the food of cognition, and cultivating the mindfulness of dharmas is apart from the food of intention.ğŸ”½Moreover, being far apart from the four abodes of consciousness, cultivating the mindfulness of the body is apart from the abode of form, cultivating the mindfulness of feelings is apart from the abode of feelings, cultivating the mindfulness of mind is apart from the abode of conceptions, and cultivating the mindfulness of dharmas is apart from the abode of volitional predispositions.

Furthermore, being apart from the five aggregates, cultivating the mindfulness of the body is far apart from the aggregate of form, cultivating the mindfulness of feelings is apart from the aggregate of feelings, cultivating the mindfulness of mind is apart from the aggregate of cognition, and cultivating the mindfulness of dharmas is apart from the aggregates of conceptions and volitional predispositions.
This is called the bodhisattva's pure cultivation of the four mindfulnesses.
Good son!
How does the bodhisattva cultivate the practice of the four right efforts?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always delight in cultivating all wholesome dharmas. For the sake of preventing unwholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen from arising, they diligently practice vigor. For the sake of distancing themselves from unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, they diligently practice vigor. For the sake of causing wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen to arise, they diligently practice vigor. For the sake of abiding without losing wholesome dharmas that have already arisen, they diligently practice vigor.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cultivate wholesome conduct for immeasurable eons. Therefore, their nature is wholesome, and they do not use skillful means to prevent unwholesomeness from arising.

If there are bodhisattvas who cultivate the four right efforts, their minds attain mastery. As for the four right efforts, at that time the bodhisattvas' minds and mental factors merge with great kindness and compassion, and they practice together. Therefore, they are called right efforts.
At that time, the bodhisattvas gradually cultivate the four bases of supernatural power:
First, desire;
Second, mind;
Third, vigor;
Fourth, wisdom.
Single-mindedly thinking of enlightenment is called desire;
Cultivating great compassion, the mind of enlightenment becomes light and agile, which is called the mind;
Far from evil dharmas, this is called vigor;
Obtaining skillful means is called wisdom.
Having cultivated the four bases of supernatural power, the bodhisattva attains four kinds of mastery:

First, mastery over lifespan. By virtue of this mastery, although born with a short lifespan, he attains a long lifespan. In order to tame sentient beings, he expounds the true Dharma to those with long lifespans, and within a long lifespan, he is able to manifest a short lifespan. Wherever this bodhisattva is born, whether among gods or humans, he attains mastery over lifespan.
Second, mastery over the body. By virtue of this mastery, he creates the body according to his mind and creates form according to his mind, manifesting deportment for the sake of sentient beings.
If the bodhisattva wishes to make his body the same as that of sentient beings, whether tall or small, he is able to do so all.

Third, attaining mastery of the Dharma, by being self-mastered, one can know all worldly and world-transcending dharmas, show all worldly matters to sentient beings, and in world-transcending practices, the mind also does not regress. Clearly knowing the profound twelve links of dependent arising, attaining unobstructed cognition, one can expound various dharmas for sentient beings.
Immeasurable sentient beings, having heard this Dharma, give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.

Fourth, attaining mastery of vows, by being self-mastered, one causes the four great oceans to combine into one ocean, neither coming nor going, without movement or change, just as before, without difference. It also causes the Sumeru mountains in the trichiliocosm to combine into one mountain, neither coming nor going, without movement or change, just as before, without difference, without obstructing the four heavenly kings and the thirty-three heavens.

If one wishes to make the trichiliocosm all become gold, the seven treasures, sandalwood, flowers, incense, necklaces, space, water, and fire, all to be accomplished according to one's wishes, this is called the bodhisattva attaining the four kinds of mastery.
